text:
Hiya :raising_hand:

I was asked a question recently: fellow marketer has a client who did a website redesign, but now want to keep the old website live to compare it to the new website.

Old website was only launched in Sept. 2020 and underperforming when it came to SEO:
• 17% of traffic from organic sources 
• 4 backlinks 
• DR 8
Client wasn't very specific about what type of performance they would like to compare, but this marketer is afraid of:
• Both websites competing with each other
• Comparisons being inaccurate anyway as there are too many variables to consider
She's having trouble formulating an answer to this client. I gave her my two cents, but wondering how Superpath SEO would respond

DR 8

Comparisons being inaccurate anyway as there are too many variables to consider
She's having trouble formulating an answer to this client. I gave her my two cents, but wondering how Superpath SEO would respond

text: Is the content (pages/blog/etc) the same just with a redesign?

elements.text: Is the content (pages/blog/etc) the same just with a redesign?

text:
I asked the same thing, the answer being that they did research into target audience, customer journey, and improved on the proposition and branding.

The goal was to make the proposition more understandable and persuasive. This is someone coming from a neuromarketing background, so there was a lot of focus on using eye-tracking to improve the website.

This answer, combined with the low DR/BLs gave me the idea that there aren't many pages to speak of to begin with

elements.text:

text:
So probably no duplicate content conflict. Assuming the goal remains organic traffic, it doesn't sound like a great idea to run competing websites for the same company/problem/products etc due to keyword cannibalisation.

Not my area of expertise but maybe someone smart can point out an A/B test website type tool that runs both options to different visitors? If such a thing exists, sounds more sensible than two competing sites.

text: I don’t know much about this, but I’ve run across a company called Intellimize that helps companies optimize pages. Not sure if they handle large scale experiments of entire websites, but I know it can help test some stuff and it might be worth looking into. It seems like a higher end product, though. <https://www.intellimize.com|https://www.intellimize.com>

text: Don’t launch the two websites simultaneously, that’s just asking for long-term headaches with SEO

elements.text: Don’t launch the two websites simultaneously, that’s just asking for long-term headaches with SEO

text: Split testing (via Optimizely, Google Optimize, etc.) is an option, but I’d really only advocate that for, e.g., the homepage and another high traffic page. If you go that path, you’d want a crystal clear understanding of the KPIs you’re monitoring to determine if the new design/value prop is a success or failure (e.g., leads generated via homepage).

elements.text: Split testing (via Optimizely, Google Optimize, etc.) is an option, but I’d really only advocate that for, e.g., the homepage and another high traffic page. If you go that path, you’d want a crystal clear understanding of the KPIs you’re monitoring to determine if the new design/value prop is a success or failure (e.g., leads generated via homepage).

text:
Me? I’d

• Preserve the existing metrics for the old site
• Sunset the current site
• Launch the new site
• Compare the metrics against each other to judge which site is winning

The redesign won’t directly help either of these metrics. Link building/generating news/generating press well.

(And DR isn’t a ‘real’ metric, I don’t put a lock of stock in it.)

text: Question for the affiliate marketers here. Have you seen your search rankings go down after Google's recent update? Reason I'm asking is because I'm considering starting an affiliate business that depends on content, but not sure if affiliates are having a hard time getting their content to rank

elements.text: Question for the affiliate marketers here. Have you seen your search rankings go down after Google's recent update? Reason I'm asking is because I'm considering starting an affiliate business that depends on content, but not sure if affiliates are having a hard time getting their content to rank

text: hey Taran, I started an affiliate site last year and it's a relatively small site only about 12 pages but it's ranking really well and it's been getting more traffic since the recent Google updates. I think if you have a background in SEO, you shouldn't have an issue. I typically see more issues with affiliate sites when they're started by new SEO's that don't have much experience.

text:
Hey SEO pros! I'm hoping to get some SEO advice for helping someone grow their organic traffic when they're starting at literally 0. I'm helping a landscaping supplier grow their website. It's a basic brochure website with landing pages and product pages. When looking Ahrefs for their products all I get is "how to build X", or "where to buy X."

Now here's my Q: how would you suggest getting started for them? My thoughts are:
• Create a blog and publish content answering common Qs I find looking at the SERPs and Ahrefs
• Update their product pages for SEO
• Fix technical things to help it rank
• Somehow get some backlinks
Am I missing anything or is this a simple process that just requires good content and consistency?

Thanks in advance!

elements.text:
Hey SEO pros! I'm hoping to get some SEO advice for helping someone grow their organic traffic when they're starting at literally 0. I'm helping a landscaping supplier grow their website. It's a basic brochure website with landing pages and product pages. When looking Ahrefs for their products all I get is "how to build X", or "where to buy X."

Now here's my Q: how would you suggest getting started for them? My thoughts are:
Create a blog and publish content answering common Qs I find looking at the SERPs and Ahrefs
Update their product pages for SEO
Fix technical things to help it rank
Somehow get some backlinks

Am I missing anything or is this a simple process that just requires good content and consistency?

Thanks in advance!

text:
Hey Ryan, you're right, consistency and patience is probably going to be the key.
I would do all those things you've listed, as well as beefing up their google my business page. Try to identify some FB groups in their local area like gardening and community groups and get them to join in relevant conversations with the aim of just getting a little bit of traffic to their site. I'd also see if they could reach out to current or past customers for a google review, which you can then also use as a testimonial on the site. A FAQ page with proper schema markup might help too.

elements.text:

text:
Are they selling locally as wholesale to landscaping companies?
Definitely get Google My Business set up. It does so much for local stuff and will many times show above bigger sites. I agree with <@U02AR2XSN1M> to get past customers to write a review on Google.
Also, a Facebook page. Facebook always shows up. ha
Citations would probably also be helpful -  yelp, bbb, etc.
